AP WORLD SYMPOSIUM '90s: Africa _ A `Nightmare Scenario'
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Bedeviled by wars, corruption, mismanagement and a burgeoning population, Africa is ending a decade of economic decline and facing what some experts say could be a ``nightmare scenario'' in the 1990s. The nightmare: increased hunger, disease, poverty and conflict on a continent already desperately poor and largely unable to survive on its own without huge doses of foreign aid. While warning of possible new violence elsewhere, many observers predict an end to war in the coming decade in Mozambique, Ethiopia, Sudan and other embattled African countries as combatants fight to stalemate and exhaustion. Namibia ended the 1980s with an election for a constitutional assembly and will enter the world of independent nations in the coming year. Peace also seems close at hand in neighboring Angola. White-ruled South Africa, which has long meddled in both those countries, appears to be changing its racial policies, albeit too slowly for some. But, with the exception of South Africa, the possibility of greater stability in those countries will not automatically bring prosperity to them or to the vast continent as a whole, say economists for the World Bank and other institutions. The 46 countries of sub-Saharan Africa _ a region of 450 million people that includes all of the continent's nations except Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, Libya, Egypt and South Africa _ had a combined gross domestic product in 1987 of about $135 billion. That was about the same as Belgium, with a population of only 10 million. That comparison, as well as any, illustrates the depths of poverty from which most African nations are struggling to emerge, only, in many cases, to slip deeper and deeperinto debt and deprivation. The World Bank, in a study that took nearly three years to complete and was released in late November, says there is a solution for Africa _ one that depends largely on Africans themselves and calls for a sharp reversal of past practices. The bank, a leading multinational lending institution, blames many of Africa's problems on corruption, poor government marked by bureaucratic bungling and misguided economic practices rooted in Marxist-Leninist theory. All that, it said, must end. It was perhaps the bluntest assessment the bank has ever made of any of the world's economies, but it may have been far easier and faster to write than the suggested changes will be coming to a continent whose rulers have too often equated power with plunder. The World Bank and others have also stressed the need for a sharp reduction in Africa's birth rate. At 3.2 percent it is the highest ever seen anywhere in the world and one that inexorably accelerates pressures for land, food and jobs and threatens new internal and cross-border conflicts. The population of sub-Saharan Africa in 1965 was only half the 450 million it is now and if current trends continue it will double again to 1 billion in 20 years. The World Bank estimates that even if fertility fell tomorrow to two children for each African family, the continent's population would continue to grow for the next 60 to 70 years. ``No region of the world has ever managed to develop with so high a rate of population growth,'' the bank said. Even in those countries where peace has arrived or is on the horizon, it is likely to take most of the new decade to revive their war-shattered economies, given optimum circumstances. Some have fallen not just 10 years behind in the development process, but 20 or 30. The World Bank's prescription for Africa called for increased aid of about 4 percent a year through the 1990s from the developed nations. But many African politicians and planners worry that the East European countries emerging from behind the Iron Curtain _ Poland, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, East Germany and possibly others _ will siphon off aid dollars as they attempt to restructure their economies with Western help. As if those problems weren't enough, a new peril arose in the 1980s that threatens Africa in the coming years with a catastrophe comparable to the droughts and famines that periodically sweep the continent. It is AIDS. Health authorities estimate that 1.5 million to 2 million Africans, mostly young adults, will die of AIDS in the 1990s, draining even further the continent's already shallow pool of skilled workers and forcing many countries to spend more scarce money on medical services.
